{{Author infobox | image = Simon Tolkien.jpg | name=Simon Tolkien | born=[[12 January]] [[1959]] | died= | education=[[wikipedia:Trinity College, Oxford|Trinity College]], [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] | occupation=Author, barrister | location=Southern California | website=[http://www.simontolkien.com/ SimonTolkien.com] }} '''Simon Mario Reuel Tolkien''' (born [[12 January]] [[1959]]) is the eldest son of [[Christopher Tolkien]] and grandson of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]. He is the only child of Christopher's first marriage, to [[Faith Tolkien|Faith Faulconbridge]]. Since [[2011]], he has acted as a director of the [[Tolkien Estate]] along with [[Baillie Tolkien]], [[Michael George Tolkien]], and [[Steven Maier]].{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://find-and-update.company-information.service.gov.uk/company/07842430/officers|articlename=The Tolkien Estate Limited|dated=|website=https://www.gov.uk|accessed=18 August 2022}} ==Biography== Simon Tolkien studied modern history at [[wikipedia:Trinity College, Oxford|Trinity College]] in the [[University of Oxford]]. After which, he embarked on a fifteen-year career as a criminal lawyer and became a [[Wikipedia:Barrister|barrister]] in [[1994]]. In [[1984]], he married Tracy Steinberg, who was Jewish.{{webcite|author=Sandee Brawarsky|articleurl=https://www.jta.org/2017/06/06/ny/hobbit-takes-on-terezin|articlename=J.R.R. Tolkien’s Jewish Great-Grandson Has A Play On Terezin|dated=6 June 6 2017|website=[https://www.jta.org/ Jewish Telegraphic Agency]|accessed=24 April 2025}} Steinberg owned and operated a vintage clothing store in Chelsea, London, called ''Steinberg & Tolkien'', which shut down in [[September]] of [[2007]]. Later, Tolkien moved to Southern California with his wife and their two children.{{webcite|author=Andrew Hough|articleurl=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/booknews/9686451/Simon-Tolkien-JRR-Tolkiens-grandson-admits-Lord-of-the-Rings-trauma.html|articlename=Simon Tolkien JRR Tolkien's grandson admits Lord of the Rings trauma|dated=18 November 2012|website=[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/ The Sunday Telegraph]|accessed=}} In [[January]] of [[2000]], Simon Tolkien began writing fiction. Tolkien's first novel, ''The Stepmother'' (published in the United States as ''Final Witness: A Novel''), was published in 2003. ''The Inheritance: A Novel'', his second book, was published on April 13, 2010 by Minotaur Books. Simon Tolkien disagreed with the then policy of his [[Tolkien Estate|grandfather's estate]] over the adaptations of his grandfather's works. As a result, he had a strained relationship with his father over that point,{{webcite|author=Devan Coggan|articleurl=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1697884.stm |articlename=Tolkien's son denies rift|dated=January 16, 2022 |accessed=January 29, 2023 |website=BBC}} however they subsequently reconciled.{{webcite|author=Devan Coggan|articleurl=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2012/nov/24/simon-tolkien-jrr-tolkien-hobbit|articlename='Being Tolkien's grandson blocked my writing ...'|dated=October 20, 2022 |accessed=January 29, 2023 |website=Guardian}} He was consulted on the development of the television series [[The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power]] and he helped develop its story and the character arcs. As a result, he is credited as a "series consultant".{{webcite|author=Devan Coggan|articleurl=https://ew.com/tv/lord-of-the-rings-the-rings-of-power-simon-tolkien-series-consultant/|articlename=How Simon Tolkien helped guide 'The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power|dated=July 19, 2022|accessed=August 1, 2022|website=[https://ew.com/ Entertainment Weekly]}} ==Family Tree== {{familytree/start}} {{familytree| | | | | | | | | | | JRR |y| EDB | | | | | | |JRR=[[J.R.R.
